VASHTI AND ESTHER CHAPTEE XL TOWARDS LONDON. In the village the excitement was intense. All that day groups of people gathered together on the green and on the doorsteps of their houses to discuss what had occurred ; but nobody had any new light to throw upon such a thrilling subject. An odd discovery made late in the day tended to increase the mystery rather than to clear it. Esther's red cloak was found folded neatly under a furze-bush on the now deserted Combley Heath, not far from the edge of the cliffs. Had she taken VOL. II. 15

VASHTI AND ESTHER 2 it off to avoid being traced, or had the murderer removed it to prevent her body from being iden tified if it were found ? There was a strong tide beneath the cliffs. If a body were not washed ashore at once, the chances were that it might be carried off to sea, and who could say where it would ultimately be found ? In the meantime the feeling was very strong against the young gamekeeper who was last seen with her. He was not popular in the village, but he had been accorded unwilling respect on account of his upright, self-denying life. Now it seemed as though this had been hypocrisy ; and a smoulder ing, because unexpressed, dislike blazed out into active unjust hatred. Adam found himself awfully alone. No one stood by him. He had no means of learning whether there were any news of Esther. At night-time he went about his work in gloomy

TOWARDS LONDON 3 silence. When morning broke he crept quietly back to the cottage. The next day, Saturday, things were much the same. He felt a strong desire hi the afternoon, when his work was all over, to walk once more over the old ground— to walk towards Combley, and to stand again where he had seen her last, with the kind blue sky above her and the cruel sea at her feet. But he dared not go. He guessed that every second person in the village had pro bably gone there to spend their half-holiday in horrible surmises. That night, however, he could not restrain his anxiety. A desire to know the worst constrained him to go to the inn. He went to the side-door, expecting that Mrs. Gay would come in answer to his knock. She had always been well disposed towards him. But the old woman, worn-out with grief and suspense, had

VASHTI AND ESTHER 4 gone to bed. It was John Gay who came stagger ing to the threshold and stood there with a candle in his hand. Half dazed with drink, he held it so that the light fell, not upon his visitor's, but upon his own face, which was, as usual, ruddy, but no longer wore the good-humoured expression which had with many served to expiate his convivial excesses. ' Have you heard — has Esther ' stammered Adam, with dry lips. At that moment a flicker of light fell upon him. John Gay recognised him, and lost his tipsy gravity at once. With hand up lifted in denunciation, he burst into a string of furious blasphemous oaths that made Adam hurry away horrified, trembling with impotent indigna tion, but with one sentence ringing like a death knell in his ear : ' Murderer, as your father were before you ! '

TOWARDS LONDON 5 The next day was Sunday. Since he had come to man's estate it had been Adam's custom every Sunday to hold a prayer-meeting in winter at the Gospel-shed, or in summer on the green. Not to do so this Sunday would be an admission of his guilt. So that afternoon, as usual, he took up his stand on the village green, and there waited. Nobody came. People passed to and fro, but with averted faces. When half an hour had elapsed, he began the service alone. He prayed and preached to empty air. The sound of his own voice, pierced with suffering, might have alarmed him had he thought of himself. His limbs were trembling, not with conscious cold, but with weakness. He had eaten scarcely anything since Thursday. Still, he omitted none of the usual prayers and petitions, and only one prayer was added — a prayer for

6 VASHTI AND ESTHER Esther Gay. Tears rained down his cheeks as he pronounced her name aloud. When the service was over, it struck him suddenly that the temperature was far lower than it had been a week before. Heavy dew — or was it rain ? — lay upon his hat and clothes. A forlorn hope brightened the outlook. What if his congre gation had not deserted him on purpose ? What if they had thought it wiser — because of the change in the weather — to go to the Gospel-shed '? They might think his grief had turned his brain if they had seen him there, praying and singing all alone. They might be waiting for him now. With new strength to sustain him, he walked rapidly in the direction of the shed ; but his hopes died away one by one as he saw that there were no lights there and no marks of footsteps in the muddy lane. The gate that led to the shed was

TOWARDS LONDON 7 tied with string, as it had been all through the summer. He turned away with a deep groan. It chanced on his way home that he passed the big room that served as a Salvationist meeting-house. That was lit up, and evidently very full. One of the windows was open, and as he stood beside it he could hear the service and see some of the people there. Some were his own people. Men and women, who Sunday after Sunday had religiously come to hear him preach the Gospel, were now joining in a hynin, the tune of which was catchy and irreverently rapid, or so it seemed to the un happy hearer. His own somewhat sanctimonious melancholy had been more grateful to these people once. Now, who was it that was standing up to give one of those stirring addresses, which, if better

8 VASHTI AND ESTHER suited to young blood, had been condemned time after time as too presumptuous and too theatrical by those who had hitherto supported him and his creed ? Humility was a strong point of the Bible Christians. He remembered once, when a long drought had seemed to force upon them a prayer for rain, how his extemporized addition, ' But it is not what we want, not what ice want, 0 Lord,' had been taken up with undoubted, if somewhat doleful, earnestness by the whole congregation. While now these same people were in the place where, if rumour were true, one of their preachers had expressed the heretical belief that anything their sinful souls might crave would come by praying, going so far as to declare that if one were to fall on his knees and ask the Almighty for a cart, he'd get it — ' name painted on and all.' But who was going to address them now ?

TOWARDS LONDON 9 Could it be Ben Skelton, whose defection from the Gospel - shed had been a severe blow to them that summer ? Yes, there was the whilom prize-fighter, no longer downcast over past trans gressions, but rubicund, cheery, and unbecomingly complacent, as though repentance and forgiveness were one and the same thing. As he began to speak Adam Mallard moved away. He dared not trust himself to listen. It was the old, old stum bling-block. The question as to whether, after all, those who had borne the heat and burden of the day should reap the same reward as those who came into the vineyard when the eventide was cool and the hardest labour over. His thoughts flew back to Esther, who, pure and sinless herself, had always given her sympathy to the unregenerate rather than to her enlightened lover. While he, ashamed of his origin, had always been hard upon

VASHTI AND ESTHER 10 the gipsies, she had upheld and helped them. He had seen her once hastily pass her foot across a footmark that might have led to a poacher's detec tion. He had suspected her more than once of moving away the board that led to a cat's trap. The fact that she had supported Madge Sollace, who before her fall was her friend, had been the cause of his righteous indignation ; but, all his protests notwithstanding, she had gone to see Madge when she was ill; she had spoken to her the last time they had been together, in defiance of his wishes. Sweet and gentle as she was, in some ways she was very strong, very faithful, tender and true. A violent sob convulsed his frame ; he dare not pursue the train of thought, for Esther was gone — lost to him for ever — and by his own fault. When Adam reached his cottage he was so

TOWARDS LONDON 11 exhausted that he never noticed his door was wide open. He sank into a chair, and let his head fall forward wearily upon his arms as they rested upon the table. How long he remained in that attitude he could not have told. When he roused himself at last, he felt refreshed as though by sleep. The night-air was blowing cold on him, and on the table before him lay a small cardboard box addressed to ' Adam Mallard, gamekeeper,' which he had overlooked before. He opened it. A few dead flowers fell out — the flowers that two days ago were sweet and fresh in Esther's hand. On a soiled piece of paper was written in a large round hand the one word only — ' Murderer.' Once more he staggered out into the air. Now he was on the road to Combley. No fear of any body being there now in the dark and the cold. He wanted to be alone on the same spot where

12 VASHTI AND ESTHER so short a while ago he and his sweetheart were together. But as he walked slowly down the road footsteps sounded in his track — light footsteps, that had his nerves not been so acutely strung he might not have heard. As they fell they seemed to fall upon his heart ; they filled him with a horrified delight. Esther had come back ; she had come to say that the misery, the remorse, of those terrible two days were all a dream. The reality was that she lived, and would be his sweetheart still. He turned and waited till the woman reached his side. It was a woman, but it was not Esther. As she emerged from the shadow of a bush of gorse, he saw that it was Madge, the wanton, who had caused their fatal quarrel. ' Where be you going ?' he asked sternly, stand ing in her way, as though to prevent her feet

TO WARDS LONDON 13 treading the same path that once Esther's feet had trodden. 'Going to find Esther,' she answered, looking at him in a dazed, despairing way that somehow angered him with its very hopelessness, its helpless pathos. 'Find Esther?' he repeated scornfully. 'That be what we all be a-trying to do. Where do you think she be, then — down there ?' pointing to the dark sea as it threw foam against the cliffs, and then receded only to wash back again in broken waves that made most miserable music to them both. ' Do you think she be down there ?' he asked again roughly. The girl shook her head. ' They say you murdered her. They be going to take you up to-morrow. Perhaps you threw her over here ; but, for all that, I believe she be

VASHTI AND ESTHER 14 alive. I be going to find her— to help her as she helped me.' ' You — you help her V he cried ' Why not? Esther, the saint, safe at home, be not the Esther we must look for now. Her fate came to her as it came to me — as it comes to every woman — God pity us all ! Let us go to find her. Come.' She made a step forward. Adam retreated. Was the girl mad? Did she mean to throw him over the cliffs — to drown herself as Esther was drowned ? ' Come — come now,' she said. ' To-morrow it will be too late ; you'll be locked up by then, and I may not be able to find my way alone.' Already she had moved on — a frail figure lightly clad, and so timorous that she started at the shadows thrown by the wind-swept bushes; yet

TOWARDS LONDON 15 quivering with eagerness to get even a little further on her way. ' Where be you going ?' he asked hoarsely. ' To London,' she replied; and she spoke in a still, hushed voice, as though she had avowed her intention of passing through the gates of hell. 'You think she be there — you think she be alive ?' ' She be alive, I feel it. We will find her — you and I who love her. We may save her even now. Will you come ?' The moon, passing from behind one cloud only to pass behind another, shone down upon her white, grieved face — her poor face that was pretty once, but on which the pain of betrayal and of desertion had left its disfiguring traces. Her sorrowful, resolute eyes lay upon him like a spell.

16 VASHTI AND ESTHER ' You will come,' she declared ; and he resisted no longer. ' I will come,' he answered. The moon was once more obscured ; but in the semi-darkness and the silence, broken only by the sounds of the sea and the rustling bushes, the man and the maid — the pharisaical preacher and the woman he had publicly condemned as sinner — walked on towards London together.

CHAPTEE XII. POOR IN A PALACE. On the morning of May 3rd it was recorded in the columns of the Morning Post : ' Mr. and Lady Violet Johnson have arrived at 40, Carlton House Terrace, for the season.' And again in a subsequent paragraph : ' Lady Marcia Legh has returned to Bruton Street from the Eiviera.' ' How odd ! I wonder how " Lady Vashti " is getting on with Kenneth,' observed Lady Marcia to herself ; and that same morning, her curiosity growing as she pondered on the Ladysmeade VOL. II. 16

When the door was opened to her, and she stepped into the palatial hall, with its historic tapestries and noble sculpture, she noted at once that there was no trace of that confusion which might be the sign of a recent arrival. Everything seemed comme il faitt, and in the best of working order. ' When did her ladyship arrive ?' she asked sharply. ' Her ladyship has not been away — that is, not lately,' was the reply from the most magnificent of the two powdered footmen who ushered her up stairs. 'H'm,' mused Lady Marcia, with a less well-

POOR IN A PALACE 19 satisfied expression. A smell of newness — new wood, new varnish, new stuffs — offended her sensitive nostrils, and as she passed through the suite of drawing-rooms she saw that, though no expense had been spared to make them beautiful, they were cruelly inartistic and overdone with decorations. The walls glistened with gilt ; the most valuable marquetries, ormolus, and buhls were heaped together with no attempt at harmony or taste. There was nothing useful, nothing com fortable, nothing really pretty. ' They look like auction-rooms. I thought "Lady Vashti" knew better,' Lady Marcia murmured to herself. That she was right in this her last surmise was presently apparent. At the farthest end of the last drawing-room was a door which, being thrown open, revealed Violet in her boudoir, a small room hung

Here were chairs into which it was a pleasure to sink down, cushions inviting repose, a few pieces of good china, a number of books for reading, not for show, and on a neat writing-table a jar of jonquils and nar cissus. Lady Violet, hi the simplest mornhig-gown, rose eagerly to meet her guest. ' Lady Marcia, this is kind of you- You have only just come to town ' ' I came on Saturday, — and you forget I am your aunt. Of course I came to see you directly I saw your announcement in the paper.' ' That was Kenneth's announcement.' 'I understand,' said Lady Marcia, sinking down into the easy-chair which Violet had drawn up close to her own. ' Just to show that you were settled down and ready to receive your friends. Quite the

POOR IN A PALACE 21 right thing to do. Kenneth is getting very worldly wise. But your friends have been calling already, and writing too ! What a lot of invitations !' her quick eye detecting a pile of cards upon the writing table. ' Have you been anywhere yet ? Are you going anywhere ? May I look ?' Already she had the cards in her hand, and was turning them over. ' Lady Mavers — I hope you are not going there ! The food is dreadful, the company worse. Odd that that earldom has never taken a position ! There has never been what you might call a misalliance, nor any scandal, and yet the family has always been so second-rate. The last Lady Mavers, this man's mother, was hopelessly dowdy ; and the present one, though a very estimable person, good to the poor, and all that — all pushing people are good to the poor — has never made any headway.

Mrs. Weyde to dinner ! Oh no ! She is smart enough, and pretty enough, but I should not trust her cook. It is her metier to be entertained, not to entertain. People should keep in then grooves. You must not go to the Duchess of Fairshire's. That would stamp you at once ; and don't dream of going to any political parties. You have nothing to gain by going to them, and it is only making yourself cheap. The Duchess of Courtland's ball — how early she is having it this year! is she "bringing out" anyone, I wonder? You must go there, whatever happens. Dread fully dull, and doubtful champagne, but quite the right place to be seen at. Mr. Catton's concert, to meet Prince and Princess Heathen — I wonder
